children: A 30-year-old woman with confirmed hyperthyroidism is further evaluated with radioactive iodine uptake testing (38% uptake) and thyroid scan.
Thyroid scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Graves disease. Radioiodine uptake is elevated in Graves disease (>30%), and this patient's thyroid scan shows diffuse uptake, consistent with the diagnosis of Graves hyperthyroidism. Graves disease is characterized by a diffusely hyperactive thyroid gland with resultant excess thyroid hormone production and subsequent suppression of thyroid-stimulating hormone secretion by the pituitary gland.

objective.__html: Diagnose Graves disease on the basis of laboratory findings and thyroid scan.

children: A 53-year-old man recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoes a comprehensive foot examination.
Physical examination findings are
shown
This patient is at highest risk for which of the following conditions?

Patients with diabetes mellitus have a proclivity to produce large, thick callus formations at pressure points, particularly if associated foot deformities, such as claw toes, are present. Extensive callus formation increases the subcutaneous pressure immediately beneath the callus and can result in a subcutaneous hemorrhage, the so-called preulcer, as seen in this patient. Preulcers must be promptly and carefully debrided to determine whether there is already an underlying ulcer.

objective.__html: Diagnose a preulcer condition caused by diabetes mellitus.

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for diminished vision in the temporal fields.
Results of visual field testing are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a pituitary tumor. This patient's visual field testing demonstrates bitemporal superior/upper quadrant visual field defects suggestive of an early lesion at the optic chiasm from a pituitary tumor. Suprasellar extension of a pituitary adenoma that compresses the optic chiasm can result in visual symptoms. The most common symptom is diminished vision in the temporal fields (bitemporal hemianopsia). A formal visual field examination is required for any tumor that abuts or compresses the optic chiasm.

objective.__html: Diagnose bitemporal quadrant visual field defects secondary to a pituitary mass.

children: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated for a 9-year history of oligomenorrhea.
Physical examination findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). This patient has hirsutism, defined as excessive growth of thick, pigmented terminal hairs in androgen-responsive areas (male pattern). Women with chronic hirsutism and menstrual irregularity most likely have PCOS. Elevated serum concentrations of androgens in women most commonly manifest with hirsutism and may also present with acne, androgenetic alopecia, and/or virilization. Hirsutism affects approximately 10% of women. The most common to least common sites are the lower abdomen and areola, the chin and upper lip, between the breasts, and on the lower back.
A 40-year-old woman with recently diagnosed primary hyperparathyroidism is evaluated with an
abdominal radiograph
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is nephrocalcinosis. Nephrocalcinosis is defined by the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma and tubules, which may be either macroscopic (as seen in this patient) or microscopic. It is the result of excessive excretion of calcium, phosphate, and/or oxalate in the urine with or without hypercalcemia. Severe hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria from primary hyperparathyroidism can lead to volume depletion and acute kidney injury, nephrolithiasis, or nephrocalcinosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose nephrocalcinosis as a complication of primary hyperparathyroidism.

children: A 59-year-old man recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoes a comprehensive ophthalmologic examination.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The patient has proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The funduscopic image shows neovascularization, cotton-wool spots, and retinal hemorrhage. Preproliferative retinopathy is manifested by cotton-wool spots, which indicate retinal infarcts. This ischemia eventually provides a stimulus for the growth of new blood vessels (neovascularization). The vessels that form are abnormal in both appearance and structure and are prone to hemorrhage. In proliferative retinopathy, blood vessel fragility can lead to significant retinal and vitreous hemorrhage. Edema of the retina may also occur. Panretinal laser photocoagulation delivers several thousand small burns to the periphery of the retina, which results in the avascular scarring and shriveling of new vessels, as
shown
A 40-year-old man with diabetes mellitus is evaluated for this
painless foot ulcer
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is neuropathic ulcer. Neuropathic ulcers are painless; are most common on the plantar surface of the feet; and have associated callus and foot deformity. The skin is warm and dry with signs of fissuring and breakdown. Neuropathic ulcers arise secondary to repetitive trauma to the skin, typically in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy and a reduced awareness of pressure or trauma to the skin.
A 77-year-old woman with confirmed hyperthyroidism is evaluated with radioiodine uptake and thyroid scan.
Thyroid scan findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a multinodular goiter. This thyroid scan shows “patchy” uptake in an enlarged gland with apparent hyperfunction in the right thyroid lobe. Multinodular goiter is the most common cause of goiter in older adults in the United States, and most goiters are benign. Radioactive iodine thyroid uptake scan is not indicated if thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is normal. However, if the TSH level is low, radioactive iodine thyroid uptake scan can be done to confirm the diagnosis of toxic multinodular goiter, which can show patchy and irregular uptake and areas of increased uptake. Thyroid ultrasonography should be performed to evaluate the characteristic of nodules in patients with progressively enlarging goiter, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy should be performed on any suspicious nodules.
A 75-year-old woman is evaluated for back pain.
A radiograph of the lumbar spine is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The patient's radiograph of the lumbar spine shows a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body secondary to osteoporosis. Compression fractures are characterized by anterior wedging associated with vertebral collapse and irregularity of the vertebral end plates.
In another patient's radiograph, asymptomatic vertebral compression fractures resulting in osteoporosis-related height loss and kyphosis are
shown
. A vertebral endplate depression without loss of vertebral height in upper lumbar vertebrae (
unfilled arrows
) and severe wedging and height loss of multiple midthoracic vertebral bodies (
filled arrows
) are shown.
A 50-year-old woman with recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoes a complete ophthalmologic examination.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This funduscopic image shows hard exudates, microaneurysms, and minor hemorrhages, findings that represent the early manifestations of diabetic retinopathy. These early changes of diabetic retinopathy are referred to as nonproliferative, or background, diabetic retinopathy. Although nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy is not typically associated with decline in visual acuity, it is a marker for future development of more significant abnormalities that can lead to vision loss.
A 43-year-old man has developed changes in skin color and is evaluated for weight loss, nausea, and weakness.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is primary adrenal insufficiency. Physical examination is helpful in the differentiation of primary (adrenal) from secondary (pituitary) causes of adrenal insufficiency; only patients with primary adrenal insufficiency have excessive adrenocorticotropic hormone, melanocyte-stimulating hormone, and pro-opiomelanocortin secretion, which results in darkly pigmented skin. Increased pigmentation is most conspicuous in areas exposed to light and areas exposed to chronic friction or pressure, including the tops of the toes or knuckles, as seen in this patient.
An example of diffuse pigmentation owing to primary adrenal insufficiency in a different patient is
shown
A 40-year-old woman with symptoms of hyperthyroidism and a suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone level is evaluated for a left thyroid nodule.
Thyroid scintigraphy
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is an autonomously functioning thyroid adenoma. The initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule begins with measuring serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level. Patients with thyroid nodules and a suppressed TSH are further evaluated with thyroid scintigraphy. A radioactive isotope is administered; the percentage taken up by the thyroid is calculated (radioactive iodine uptake); and an image is obtained (thyroid scan). Hot nodules concentrate radioactive iodine to a greater extent than normal thyroid tissue, as seen in this patient's thyroid scintigraphy, which shows increased uptake in the lower left thyroid lobe. Autonomously functioning thyroid nodules (toxic nodules) are mostly benign and there is no need for biopsy.

objective.__html: Diagnose an autonomously functioning thyroid adenoma.

title: Question 13

children: A 44-year-old woman is evaluated for palpitations, heat intolerance, diplopia, and proptosis.
The neck is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Graves disease, a common autoimmune thyroid disorder and the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. In this image, both lobes and the isthmus of the thyroid gland are enlarged. Common definitions of goiter include a lateral lobe that is larger than the examiner's thumb and a thyroid lobe measuring greater than 3 cm (width) × 2 cm (depth) × 5 cm (length). The presence of hyperthyroid symptoms, eye findings, and goiter in this patient most strongly suggest the diagnosis of Graves disease.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated for galactorrhea.
Gadolinium-enhanced MRI of the brain is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A pituitary tumor is
seen
on the patient's gadolinium-enhanced brain MRI (
white arrow

). On unenhanced MRI, normal pituitary tissue, most sellar lesions, pituitary adenomas, and other pituitary tumors have a signal of similar or slightly greater intensity compared with that of central nervous system tissue; hemorrhage into the pituitary gland results in a high-intensity signal. On gadolinium-enhanced MRI, normal pituitary tissue is of higher intensity than surrounding central nervous system tissue. Because pituitary micro- and macroadenomas usually have less gadolinium uptake than surrounding normal pituitary tissue, they appear hypodense, as in this patient's image.
A 56-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
His profile is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is Cushing syndrome. This patient with hypertension and diabetes mellitus
demonstrates

many of the physical findings associated with Cushing syndrome, including facial plethora, abdominal striae (especially if reddish purple and >1 cm in width), abdominal obesity, dorsocervical fat pad, supraclavicular fat pads, and ecchymoses, most easily seen on the right arm of this frontal view.
A 79-year-old man is evaluated for several years of right posterior hip pain that is most notable with walking.
A radiograph of the pelvis is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Paget disease of bone. The radiograph of the pelvis shows mixed osteolytic changes and increased bone density along the iliac side of the right sacroiliac joint, characteristic of Paget disease of bone. Paget disease of bone results from an accelerated rate of bone remodeling caused by abnormal osteoclast function. Bone scintigraphy typically shows enhanced radionuclide uptake in affected bone due to increased blood flow and bone remodeling, and it will demonstrate the extent of bony involvement. The increased activity
shown
on scintigraphy in this patient corresponds with the findings on plain radiograph.

Paget disease commonly affects the skull, spine, pelvis, and long bones of the lower extremities. Although asymptomatic in most patients, pain may result from bony overgrowth or may be due to accelerated osteoarthritis or nerve impingement associated with excess bone formation. Many patients are diagnosed following the incidental discovery of an elevated alkaline phosphatase level.
